description.narrative: 20,000 people to be reached through HIV Behaviour Change project (Community Conversations on HIV and HIV Radio message campaign) by end 2015

comment.narrative: At the end of 2015 approximately 11,000 people had been reached through Community Conversations on HIV
Continuation of 2015 target

Total: 236 In Puntland 25 judges participated in 3 days of HIV and AIDS sensitization training. In Somaliland, 68 police officers received HIV and AIDS training. In SL UNDP’s Gender project provided information on HIV to 143 people (M:32 and W: 111) in Berbera under their Community Conversations initiative.

activity-description.narrative: Identify and Register 380 youth in 4 centers; Conduct full Programme Orientation Training for all UNDP implementing partners, and new facilitators, mentors, and center management staff

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
The overall objective of this project is to contain and prevent violent conflict by engaging youth at risk through the creation of employment and livelihood opportunities at the district level.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
Youth for Change Initiative, Phase II- Support to the improvement of security and the reduction of violence
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
Youth for Change Joint Initiative – Provision of social and economic alternatives to crime and violence for children and youth
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
Number of youth registered compared with that of graduated youth.

comment.narrative: Results from Y@R and Y4C I and II.

Output 2.1: Youth and children are identified as per the agreed criteria for selection in the target districts. output 2.2 Systems (for registration) and services (case management, psycho-social testing) for rehabilitation is implemented
- 380 youth are identified - 4 centers are fully staffed and prepared for implementation

90 youth beneficiaries were identified and selected into the programme, In the district of Bosaso, from 16 villages and 4 IDP camps in Bosaso. The Beneficiaries are benefiting from social rehabilitation programme, have been constantly mentored and provided incentives for lunch and transport.
Two caseloads of 80 each (160 participants, 50% girls) have been identified and selected into the programme from 8 districts in Mogadishu. The beneficiaries are benefiting from social rehabilitation programme, have been constantly mentored and provided incentives for lunch and transport

activity-description.narrative: Enhancing Climate Resilience of the Vulnerable Communities and Ecosystems in Somalia.

description.narrative: Number of Land Use Policies and implementation roadmaps developed that support sustainable Natural Resources Management

comment.narrative: Land use policies and proper enforcement mechanisms on land-use do not exist in all zones of Somalia. This has led to conflicts over natural resources and exacerbated tensions between grazing nomadic pastoralists and sedentary agro-pastoralists. Rural populations are also using land in an ad-hoc manner, cutting trees to produce charcoal and encroaching on grazing lands.

1. One Land Use Policy for at least one zone developed. 2. A gender-sensitive climate compatible National Development Plan (2017-19) finalised 3. At least 300 women trained in adaptation technologies as a foundation for starting sustainable technology marketing enterprises 4. One Project board meeting held.

1. At the national level, Somalia is covered under Regional Climate Change Strategy for the member states of Intergovernmental Agency for Development (IGAD) with support from the UNDP/GEF/LDCF Project. IGAD Regional Climate Change Strategy sets the framework for the National Climate Change Policy for Somalia being formulated by the UNDP/GEF/LDCF Project. The national land policy draft finalized in Somaliland and its review at regional and district level completed. Puntland Land Policy formulation is still ongoing with MoEWT. 2. National Disaster Management Policy to be initiated after the formulation of National Climate Change Policy which is currently under initiation stage and anticipation is to have it completed by the end of 2017. In addition, 2 existing disaster management policies (Somaliland and Puntland) have been updated while the one for South Central to be part of 2017 LOA with Somali Disaster Management Agency (SoDMA)
3.A total of 280 women (160-Somaliland and 120-Puntland) have been trained on adaptation technologies and benefited upscaling activities i.e. fodder production, reforestation -water harvesting .and small scale business cooperatives.
4. Two project Board Meeting were conducted in October and December 2016 with participants from the Federal Government and regional member States key sector ministries. Key Decisions from the meetings were as follows: a. Project Board Meeting -28th October 2016: • Quarterly Progress Report for the quarter ending 30 September 2016 to be shared with participants of the Project Board Meeting • Mid-term evaluation of the project should focus on whether the investments under this project have brought positive changes to the lives of the people • The impacts of the training and policies should be assessed and any recommendations for future improvements should help in revising the project logic • Project should also look into possibilities of expanding the focus according to new administrative realities in Somali

description.narrative: Number of Land Use Policies and implementation roadmaps developed that support sustainable Natural Resources Management

comment.narrative: Land use policies and proper enforcement mechanisms on land-use do not exist in all zones of Somalia. This has led to conflicts over natural resources and exacerbated tensions between grazing nomadic pastoralists and sedentary agro-pastoralists. Rural populations are also using land in an ad-hoc manner, cutting trees to produce charcoal and encroaching on grazing lands.

1. One Land Use Policy for at least one zone developed. 2. A gender-sensitive climate compatible National Development Plan (2017-19) finalised 3. At least 300 women trained in adaptation technologies as a foundation for starting sustainable technology marketing enterprises 4. One Project board meeting held.

1. At the national level, Somalia is covered under Regional Climate Change Strategy for the member states of Intergovernmental Agency for Development (IGAD) with support from the UNDP/GEF/LDCF Project. IGAD Regional Climate Change Strategy sets the framework for the National Climate Change Policy for Somalia being formulated by the UNDP/GEF/LDCF Project. The national land policy draft finalized in Somaliland and its review at regional and district level completed. Puntland Land Policy formulation is still ongoing with MoEWT. 2. National Disaster Management Policy to be initiated after the formulation of National Climate Change Policy which is currently under initiation stage and anticipation is to have it completed by the end of 2017. In addition, 2 existing disaster management policies (Somaliland and Puntland) have been updated while the one for South Central to be part of 2017 LOA with Somali Disaster Management Agency (SoDMA)
3.A total of 280 women (160-Somaliland and 120-Puntland) have been trained on adaptation technologies and benefited upscaling activities i.e. fodder production, reforestation -water harvesting .and small scale business cooperatives.
4. Two project Board Meeting were conducted in October and December 2016 with participants from the Federal Government and regional member States key sector ministries. Key Decisions from the meetings were as follows: a. Project Board Meeting -28th October 2016: • Quarterly Progress Report for the quarter ending 30 September 2016 to be shared with participants of the Project Board Meeting • Mid-term evaluation of the project should focus on whether the investments under this project have brought positive changes to the lives of the people • The impacts of the training and policies should be assessed and any recommendations for future improvements should help in revising the project logic • Project should also look into possibilities of expanding the focus according to new administrative realities in Somali

title.narrative: Support to the Federal State Formation Process/StEFS

description.narrative: The project provides immediate, short- and medium-term assistance to the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS) to facilitate state formation and federalism processes, as well as to emerging states to establish basic functional capacity.

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia

title.narrative: PSG 11 State FormationFederalism Project Initiation Final for Signature Rev 2

description.narrative: PIP (Activity 1-6): Set of initial activities to support the FGS to form IRAs. StEFS (Outputs 1-6): Addresses capacity development needs at the emerging FMS level and supports the FGS to facilitate new state formation and federalism processes.

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

provider-org.narrative: United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia
United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia
United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia
United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia
United Nations Multi Partner Trust Fund for Somalia

description.narrative:
PIP:
Activity 1: 1.1: # of reconciliation conferences organized by IRAs/FGS 1.2: IRAs charters drafted through community/representatives consultation and feedback process 1.3: % representation of women in reconciliation process/forums
Activity 2: 2.1: Boundaries & Federation Commission (BFC) formation act is endorsed in parliament 2.2: % of women in BFC 2.3: % of members receive office equipment and tools to work 2.4: Number of BFC members trained on framework and policy on boundary and federalism process
Activity 3: 3.1: % of IRAs target population receive good governance and federalism messages and # of IRAs broadcasting good governance and federalism messages 3.2: # of workshop/seminars/conferences conducted
Activity 4: 4.1: # of technical advisors hired and are actively supporting state formation and reconciliation processes (disaggregated by sex) 4.2: % of federal directorate receive office equipment support 4.3: # of MoIFA staff who receive basic training to support federalism (disaggregated by sex) 4.4: # of federal- IRA consultative meetings organized
Activity 5: 5.1: % of IRAs receiving capacity building support 5.2: % (and #) of IRA staff trained in basic management functions (disaggregated by sex) 5.3: # of IRAs offices rehabilitated 5.4: Full-fledged project document to support interim administration developed
StEFS:
Output 1: 1.1: # of inclusive mediation processes supported and led by IRA/FGS
Output 2: 2.1: # of technical advisors and interns provided to BFC to assist in policy development and implementation (disaggregated by sex) 2.3: # of approved draft policy/strategy on federalism and boundary demarcation 2.4: # of technical advisors and interns provided to MoIFA/OPM to assist in policy development and implementation on federalism process (disaggregated by sex)
Output 3: 3.2: # of new or established infrastructure projects undertaken in the interim administrations/states
Output 4: 4.1: # of baseline assessments co

comment.narrative:
PIP:
Activity 1: - 2015: While there is large political will, diverging opinions exist and broad-based political and civil agreements have not yet been fully realized. - 2016: Reconciliation process towards state formation has been undertaken in ISWA, GIA and IJA. Hiraan and Middle Shabelle reconciliation process is to be initiated.
Activity 2: - 2015: Establishment Act for the BFC drafted and tabled for parliament’s review and approval. No Commissioners in place; to be appointed after the Act is passed. - 2016: Establishment act for the BFC approved and the commission established.
Activity 3: - 2015: No baseline figures exist on the target population receiving good governance and federalism messages in the IRAs; No conferences conducted in the IRAs on federalism. - 2016: No clear or ad hoc information campaign available on federalism process.
Activity 4: - 2015: Department specifically in charge of federal affairs exists within the Ministry, but with insufficient capacity, and an interim administration does not exist; ad hoc support to MoIFA; MoIFA staff have limited knowledge on federalism and management; ad hoc consultative meetings organized, inclusive of PSG 1 regions. - 2016: Department specifically in charge of federal affairs exists within the Ministry, but with insufficient capacity to facilitate federalism.
Activity 5: - 2015: Short term or ad hoc support available to the emerging states; ad hoc/no training received by the IRAs officials; no office rehabilitated (only in IJA provided by SSF). - 2016: Short term or ad hoc support available to the emerging states. There is no medium term support strategy towards IRAs support.
StEFS:
Output 1: 1.1: Nine reconciliation conferences/meetings have been held in ISWA, GIA and Hiraan/Middle Shabelle (18% women participants at conferences held in Q1 2016) Output 2: 2.1: Two technical officers (2M) and three interns (2M:1W) provided to support the BFC (together with short-term internat

PIP: Activity 1: 1.1 Two (2) reconciliation conferences organized by IRAs/FGS 1.2 Four (4) IRAs’ charters drafted through community/representatives consultation and feedback process 1.3 At least 30% representation of women in reconciliation process/forums
Activity 2: 2.1 Boundaries and Federation Commission (BFC) is functional 2.2 At least 20% of women in BFC 2.3 90% of members receive office equipment and tools to work 2.4 100% of BFC members trained on framework and policy on boundary and federalism process
Activity 3: 3.1 N/A; Four (4) IRAs broadcasting good governance and federalism messages 3.2 Two (2) workshop/seminars/conference conducted
Activity 4: 4.1 Three (3) technical advisors hired and are actively supporting state formation and reconciliation processes 4.2 At least 70% of federal directorate receive office equipment support 4.3 35 of MoIFA staff receive basic training to support federalism (at least 30% women) 4.4 Six (6) federal-IRA consultative meetings organized
Activity 5: 5.1 100% of IRAs receiving capacity building support 5.2 70% of IRA staff/officials trained in basic management functions (at least 30% women) 5.3 Two (2) IRAs offices rehabilitated 5.4 Yes: Fully fledged project document endorsed to support interim administration
STEFS ANNUAL (Q4) 2016 TARGETS: Output 1: 1.1 Two Hiraan/Middle Shabelle draft charter and draft constitution developed 1.2 Two mediation processes supported, facilitated and led by Interim Administration and FGS (at least 30% gender representation) 1.3 50% of state administration staff trained in conflict management and community problem solving in at least three interim federal states (with at least 30% gender representation) 1.4 At least two consultations undertaken between Interim Administration and FGS on federalism and federal state endorsement criteria (at least 30% gender representation) 1.5 Additional Target: At least a total of 600 community members/leaders trained in conflict management and co

PIP (Q1 2016):
Activity 1: 1.1. Three (3) reconciliation conferences organized by IRAs/FGS in Q1 2016 1.2 Total of three (3) IRAs’ charters drafted through community/representatives consultation and feedback process so far; 0 in Q1 2016 (state formation process for Hiraan/Middle Shabelle initiated but stalled) 1.3 18% representation of women in reconciliation process/forums in Q1 2016
Activity 2: 2.1 Yes: BFC is functional 2.2 10% of women in BFC 2.3 100% of members receive office equipment and tools to work 2.4 89% of BFC members trained on framework and policy on boundary and federalism process in Q1 2016 (7M:1F)
Activity 3: 3.1 N/A; Three (3) IRAs broadcasting good governance and federalism messages in Q1 2016 (Hiraan & Middle Shabelle not yet formed) 3.2 Six (6) workshop/seminars/conference conducted in Q1 2016
Activity 4: 4.1 Two (2) technical advisors hired and are actively supporting state formation and reconciliation processes (both male) 4.2 50% of federal directorate departments received office equipment support in 2015. No new office equipment provided in Q1 2016. 4.3 One (1) MoIFA staff received basic training to support federalism in Q1 2016 (male only) 4.4 Three (3) federal-IRA consultative meetings organized in Q1 2016
Activity 5: 5.1 50% of IRAs receiving capacity building support 5.2 84 IRA staff/officials trained in basic management functions (25% women) 5.3 One (1) IRA office rehabilitation initiated and in progress in Q1 2016 5.4 Yes: Fully fledged project document endorsed to support interim administration in January 2016 and signed in March 2016
STEFS ANNUAL (Q4) 2016 RESULTS: Output 1: a) Hirshabelle interim Administration in Q4 2016, and drafted a charter for the HirShabelle interim administration. b) Four (4) mediation processes supported, facilitated and led by FMSFGS in Merka, Balanbale, Gedo and Galkayo between April and December 2016 (with 26% women representation) c) 22% with 35% Women of state administration staff; (77

Activity 5: 5.1: % of IRAs receiving capacity building support 5.2: % (and #) of IRA staff trained in basic management functions (disaggregated by sex) 5.3: # of IRAs offices rehabilitated 5.4: Full-fledged project document to support interim administration developed
StEFS:
Output 1: 1.1: # of inclusive mediation processes supported and led by IRA/FGS
Output 2: 2.1: # of technical advisors and interns provided to BFC to assist in policy development and implementation (disaggregated by sex) 2.3: # of approved draft policy/strategy on federalism and boundary demarcation 2.4: # of technical advisors and interns provided to MoIFA/OPM to assist in policy development and implementation on federalism process (disaggregated by sex)
Output 3: 3.2: # of new or established infrastructure projects undertaken in the interim administrations/states
Output 4: 4.1: # of baseline assessments co

comment.narrative:
PIP:
Activity 1: - 2015: While there is large political will, diverging opinions exist and broad-based political and civil agreements have not yet been fully realized. - 2016: Reconciliation process towards state formation has been undertaken in ISWA, GIA and IJA. Hiraan and Middle Shabelle reconciliation process is to be initiated.
Activity 2: - 2015: Establishment Act for the BFC drafted and tabled for parliament’s review and approval. No Commissioners in place; to be appointed after the Act is passed. - 2016: Establishment act for the BFC approved and the commission established.
Activity 3: - 2015: No baseline figures exist on the target population receiving good governance and federalism messages in the IRAs; No conferences conducted in the IRAs on federalism. - 2016: No clear or ad hoc information campaign available on federalism process.
Activity 4: - 2015: Department specifically in charge of federal affairs exists within the Ministry, but with insufficient capacity, and an interim administration does not exist; ad hoc support to MoIFA; MoIFA staff have limited knowledge on federalism and management; ad hoc consultative meetings organized, inclusive of PSG 1 regions. - 2016: Department specifically in charge of federal affairs exists within the Ministry, but with insufficient capacity to facilitate federalism.
Activity 5: - 2015: Short term or ad hoc support available to the emerging states; ad hoc/no training received by the IRAs officials; no office rehabilitated (only in IJA provided by SSF). - 2016: Short term or ad hoc support available to the emerging states. There is no medium term support strategy towards IRAs support.
StEFS:
Output 1: 1.1: Nine reconciliation conferences/meetings have been held in ISWA, GIA and Hiraan/Middle Shabelle (18% women participants at conferences held in Q1 2016) Output 2: 2.1: Two technical officers (2M) and three interns (2M:1W) provided to support the BFC (together with short-term internat

PIP: Activity 1: 1.1 Two (2) reconciliation conferences organized by IRAs/FGS 1.2 Four (4) IRAs’ charters drafted through community/representatives consultation and feedback process 1.3 At least 30% representation of women in reconciliation process/forums
Activity 2: 2.1 Boundaries and Federation Commission (BFC) is functional 2.2 At least 20% of women in BFC 2.3 90% of members receive office equipment and tools to work 2.4 100% of BFC members trained on framework and policy on boundary and federalism process
Activity 3: 3.1 N/A; Four (4) IRAs broadcasting good governance and federalism messages 3.2 Two (2) workshop/seminars/conference conducted

comment.narrative:
Master Plan Prepared and agreed by April 2016
MoCA, ICRIC and OC staffed up and capacitated to perform their mandates
Puntland institutions and IRA institutions staffed up and capacitated to perform their mandates and to engage in the national constitutional review process

1. The revision of 10 chapters of the constitution was completed. 2. The reviewed and agreed ten chapters were tabled at the parliament. 3. Public outreach and general civic education on constitutional review process was launched in Baidoa. 4. Completion of Office Set-up and Technical expertise for MoCA. 5. Functional website of Federal MoCA (www.moca.gov.so), was developed and launched 6. A one-day awareness workshop on constitutional review conducted for Somalia women (10 M, 45 W). 7. Revision of the Provisional Constitution were compiled. 8. All stakeholders agreed during PSG 1 meeting in June 2016 that no major activities shall be undertaken for constitutional review until after the completion of the electoral process. Since the operational closure of project on 30th Jun 2016, no activity was undertaken during Q-3, 2016.

Master Plan Prepared and agreed by April 2016
MoCA, ICRIC and OC staffed up and capacitated to perform their mandates
Puntland institutions and IRA institutions staffed up and capacitated to perform their mandates and to engage in the national constitutional review process

1. The revision of 10 chapters of the constitution was completed. 2. The reviewed and agreed ten chapters were tabled at the parliament. 3. Public outreach and general civic education on constitutional review process was launched in Baidoa. 4. Completion of Office Set-up and Technical expertise for MoCA. 5. Functional website of Federal MoCA (www.moca.gov.so), was developed and launched 6. A one-day awareness workshop on constitutional review conducted for Somalia women (10 M, 45 W). 7. Revision of the Provisional Constitution were compiled. 8. All stakeholders agreed during PSG 1 meeting in June 2016 that no major activities shall be undertaken for constitutional review until after the completion of the electoral process. Since the operational closure of project on 30th Jun 2016, no activity was undertaken during Q-3, 2016.

comment.narrative: 1. 768 (M: 610 W:158) MPs and Staff trained on legislative drafting, principles of democracy and democratic society, RoP, public outreach etc. 2. Video and Teleconference equipment provided to NFP and Puntland to improve communication. 3. Construction of security perimeter walls for NFP, Puntland and Somaliland HoRs completed. 4. Development of Somaliland House of Elders (Guurti) Strategic Plan 2016-2021. 5. NFP has completed follow up of ABRIMO recommendations of the third party assessment. 6. The project produced a Parliamentary Regional Offices Manual for Somaliland parliament. 7. NFP legal archiving has been upgraded. 8. Southwest State Assembly received sound system equipment to support parliamentary members to conduct debates effectively.

1. 768 (M: 610 W:158) MPs and Staff trained on legislative drafting, principles of democracy and democratic society, RoP, public outreach etc. 2. Video and Teleconference equipment provided to NFP and Puntland to improve communication. 3. Construction of security perimeter walls for NFP, Puntland and Somaliland HoRs completed. 4. Development of Somaliland House of Elders (Guurti) Strategic Plan 2016-2021. 5. NFP has completed follow up of ABRIMO recommendations of the third party assessment. 6. The project produced a Parliamentary Regional Offices Manual for Somaliland parliament. 7. NFP legal archiving has been upgraded. 8. Southwest State Assembly received sound system equipment to support parliamentary members to conduct debates effectively.

OUTPUT 1 Indicator 1: Number of new recruits (disaggregated by sex, location, institution, position) within public institutions supported by UNDP Indicator 2: Percentage of direct supervisors satisfied with new recruits
OUTPUT 2 Indicator 1: # of Civil Service Laws reviewed or amendments proposed Indicator 2: # of HR Management Framework submitted
OUTPUT 3 Indicator 1: # of Civil Service Training / Capacity Development Policy submitted Indicator 2: Number of Civil Service Training Institutes established Indicator 3: Number of trainings facilitated for civil servants Indicator 4: Number of consolidated reports produced from a consolidated tracking database for training provided to civil servants
OUTPUT 4 Indicator 1: Number of organizational / functional reviews carried out Indicator 2: Number of new organograms submitted for approval Indicator 3: Number of change management plans developed and submitted for approval Indicator 4: Number of institutions supported with infrastructure and equipment
OUTPUT 5 Indicator 1: Number of policy development guidelines developed Indicator 2: Number of proposals developed to clarify roles and responsibilities of individual government institutions Indicator 3: Number of inter-ministerial coordination meetings facilitated
OUTPUT 6 Indicator 1: Number of institutional coordination arrangements for development policy drafted Indicator 2: Number of Statistical Strategies reviewed, amended, updated or developed Indicator 3: Number of processes, tools and guidelines for collection and storage of data developed Indicator 4: # of Aid Coordination Architecture developed and institutionalized Indicator 5: Number of DAD/AIMS systems operational Indicator 6: Number of Quarterly reports on Aid Flows are generated through DAD/AIMS
OUTPUT 7 Indicator 1: Number of Project Board meetings are convened as scheduled Indicator 2: Number of Project progress reports generated periodically or monitored, reviewed and evaluated Indicator 3: Percent

Output 1: Capacity gaps in priority institutions filled in placing staff and advisors in priority positions.

description.narrative: 1. Number of regions that adopt quota system for women 2. Number of women that contest in national elections supported by UNDP. 3. Number of electoral policies that mainstream gender equality

comment.narrative: 1. No quotas for women in all 3 regions. 2. Data on women candidates for electoral offices at national level not available 3. No gender mainstreamed electoral policies

- Gender Policies adopted in Puntland and Federal - Review of Provisional Federal Constitution includes gender perspectives. - GBV/Sexual offense laws are adopted at least two regions. - At least 50% of PL and SL ministries appoint gender focal points and regularly participates inter-agency gender coordination mechanism to strengthen Gender mainstreaming

1. National Gender Policy for FGS is being drafted. GEWE has hired an international gender expert to support MOWHRD developed NGP and carryout consultations. In PL, the draft NGP has been improved and envisaged to advocate for its adoption in 2016 2. Review of the Provisional Federal Constitution has been slowed by the political disagreements on the electoral model. However, the FGS decided to include the 30% of reserved seats for women in both houses. Advocacy towards the enforcement of this decision is ongoing and planned to intensify before the election happens. 3. Sexual Offence law was adopted in PL in this reporting period. SOB in SL is tabled to the parliament for discussion and approval. FL SOB is being public consulted 4. 17 and 10 ministries have now GFPs in SL and PL respectively. No inter-agency gender coordination mechanism is convened in this year.

description.narrative: 1. Number of regions that adopt quota system for women 2. Number of women that contest in national elections supported by UNDP. 3. Number of electoral policies that mainstream gender equality

comment.narrative: 1. No quotas for women in all 3 regions. 2. Data on women candidates for electoral offices at national level not available 3. No gender mainstreamed electoral policies

- Gender Policies adopted in Puntland and Federal - Review of Provisional Federal Constitution includes gender perspectives. - GBV/Sexual offense laws are adopted at least two regions. - At least 50% of PL and SL ministries appoint gender focal points and regularly participates inter-agency gender coordination mechanism to strengthen Gender mainstreaming

1. National Gender Policy for FGS is being drafted. GEWE has hired an international gender expert to support MOWHRD developed NGP and carryout consultations. In PL, the draft NGP has been improved and envisaged to advocate for its adoption in 2016 2. Review of the Provisional Federal Constitution has been slowed by the political disagreements on the electoral model. However, the FGS decided to include the 30% of reserved seats for women in both houses. Advocacy towards the enforcement of this decision is ongoing and planned to intensify before the election happens. 3. Sexual Offence law was adopted in PL in this reporting period. SOB in SL is tabled to the parliament for discussion and approval. FL SOB is being public consulted 4. 17 and 10 ministries have now GFPs in SL and PL respectively. No inter-agency gender coordination mechanism is convened in this year.

description.narrative: Number of district administrations established and trained (2015) 2016 output 2.1 # of gender-fair DPSCs established with approved ToRs output 2.3 # of reconciliation initiatives undertaken per target district

comment.narrative:
Baseline: - 0 DPSCs formed and trained - 5 Caretaker Administrations deployed. - 0 Interim Administration established
.

2016
Output 2.1: 1 per district
Output 2.3 3

2016 2.1.1: Total 11: 1 per district for 11 District (out of 15 district project targeting) With total of 244 DPSCs Members (M: 213; F: 31) 2.3.2 : 4 Dstricts initiated their own reconciliation process to address various issues, including sub-clan disputes, power sharing, clan grievances and pastoral territorial disputes. Among the districts that have implemented reconciliation activities are: Barawe, Hudur, Mahas, Elbur and Warshiekh.
